page.title: 06CIDER MAKING, HIGH HAM
page.content: Cider is still made in the traditional way in High Ham. It takes about 356kg apples to make a hogshead, about 245 litres, of cider. The apples are tipped into a large mincing machine. Most of these are now driven by tractor, but formerly 4 men turned 2 handles. The apples are pulped into a "pummace", which is put in a press, in 10cm layers, alternating with equal layers of straw, to a depth of 1m. The head of the press is screwed down to compress this "cheese" and squeeze out all the juice which flows into a wooden tub. From here it is dipped and poured into a wooden bucket with a strainer at the bottom, and then poured into barrels. The juice is left to "work" in the barrels for several weeks before the cider is ready to drink. The discarded "cheese" is fed to cattle.
